thread.title: REGION: Friday night football games boost players, coaches -- and athletic budgets
thread.title_full: REGION: Friday night football games boost players, coaches -- and athletic budgets - Press Enterprise

author: CRAIG SHULTZ
title: REGION: Friday night football games boost players, coaches -- and athletic budgets
text:
BY CRAIG SHULTZ Oct. 1, 2015 Updated: Oct. 2, 2015 6:35 a.m. REGION: Friday night football games boost players, coaches -- and athletic budgets Print Photo Share Pin It 1 of 29 More Galleries ADVERTISEMENT A referee tosses a coin as teams captains watch before a game between Redlands' East Valley High and Rialto's Carter High on Friday, Sept. 25. DOUG BENC, CONTRIBUTING PHOTOGRAPHER Related article » ON THE FIELD
Tahquitz High vs. Temecula Valley
When: 7 p.m. Friday, Oct. 2
Where: 4425 Titan Trail, Hemet
Overall record: 1-3
Norco High vs. Serrano High (Phelan)
When: 7 p.m. Friday, Oct. 2
Where: 2065 Temescal Ave., Norco
Overall record: 3-1
Temescal Canyon (bye week)
Next opponent: at Perris High on Oct. 9
Overrall record: 1-4
It’s a Friday night tradition. Thousands of people jam into high school football stadiums to watch young men compete on the gridiron.
And while most eyes are on the players, hundreds of other people are involved in the spectacle known as Friday Night Lights.
Not only is it an important night for the players and coaches, it’s also big for band members, cheerleaders and, frankly, athletic budgets.
Proceeds from ticket sales help cover costs for other sports at many schools. The money is used to pay for officials and fees for tournaments in non-revenue-generating sports, while sales of concessions and souvenirs pump up the coffers of student government, booster clubs and other school groups.
“It helps create our athletic budget,” Norco Athletic Director Josh Cameron said. “It’s very important for us to be able to earn money for a lot of things throughout the year.”
Most high schools host five varsity games over 11 weeks between late August and mid-November and some of the top-ranked football teams in Southern California play in the region.
“It’s a huge event every home game,” said Mike Sims, athletic director at Tahquitz High in Hemet. “It’s a long day. When the game is over, our day is not over.”
HOME SCHOOL
Norco High, which has a long tradition of elite football teams – having qualified for the playoffs 28 consecutive seasons – draws up to 5,000 fans to its home games.
Cameron starts planning for Cougar home games first thing Monday, when he emails the opposing athletic director to discuss logistics, such as where to park buses and sideline etiquette.
“Early on in the week, we’re just making sure both parties know what to expect,” he said.
He also makes sure security is set. On game nights, school security staff is joined by four Riverside County sheriff’s deputies and 10 private guards, who watch the stands and gate, Cameron said.
One of the challenges is deciding who gets the 60 passes available to be on the Norco sideline during the game.
“Norco has a long tradition of people wanting to come and watch games,” Cameron said, adding friends, families and former players and coaches usually get the passes.
Game days start early with the maintenance crew readying the field and stands. As the game gets closer, teachers and other school staff members sell and take tickets. Cameron will greet the referees.
The snack bar, overseen by the student government, is operated by the choir and band, which keep the proceeds. The boosters also hold a barbecue and sell shirts and hats.
VISITING SCHOOL
Sims is much less stressed when Tahquitz plays a road game.
“The visiting piece is a lot easier,” he said. “Being the home team is a headache. It’s a long, long day.”
